term.title: ipso-attack

item.text: The attachment of an entering group to a position in an aromatic compound already carrying a substituent group (other than hydrogen). The entering group may displace that substituent group but may also itself be expelled or migrate to a different position in a subsequent step. The term 'ipso-substitution' is not used, since it is synonymous with substitution. For example: [image: Not defined] where E + is an electrophile and Z is a substituent (other than hydrogen).

sources.item: PAC, 1994, 66, 1077. 'Glossary of terms used in physical organic chemistry (IUPAC Recommendations 1994)' on page 1128 (https://doi.org/10.1351/pac199466051077)

Users of these terms are encouraged to include the version of a term with its use and to check regularly for updates to term definitions that you are using.
